title: Attainment gap between UK white and minority ethnic medical students varies by ethnicity and medical school
description: The size of the gap in academic achievement between white and minority ethnic medical students in the UK varies considerably, depending on their individual ethnicity and which medical school they attended, finds the largest study of its kind, published in the open access journal BMJ Open.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: NASA's Perseverance rover deciphers ancient history of Martian lake
description: Marking its 1,000th Martian day on the Red Planet, NASA's Perseverance rover recently completed its exploration of the ancient river delta that holds evidence of a lake that filled Jezero Crater billions of years ago. The six-wheeled scientist has to date collected a total of 23 samples, revealing the geologic history of this region of Mars in the process.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researcher discovers new technique for photon detection
description: University of Central Florida researcher Debashis Chanda, a professor at the NanoScience Technology Center, has developed a new technique to detect photons—elementary particles that span from visible light to radio frequencies and are instrumental in carrying cellular communication.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Is age linked to the picture of the perfect partner?
description: How do women picture the partner of their dreams? And how does this vary between women based on their age? A team of researchers led by the University of Göttingen investigated the complex relationships between age and preferences for a partner in a large, international sample of single women.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Exploring how the convergence of automation and AI reshapes organic chemistry research
description: Recently, National Science Open magazine published online a review article led by Professor Fanyang Mo (School of Materials Science and Engineering, Peking University) and Professor Yuntian Chen (Eastern Institute of Technology, Ningbo).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Understanding the key to predicting heat events in Central Europe
description: The surface temperature of the North Atlantic plays an important role in the occurrence of heat waves in Europe. However, researchers at the GEOMAR Helmholtz Centre for Ocean Research in Kiel have shown that it is not high water temperatures but low water temperatures that are responsible for heat events on land.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study finds configuration of green spaces in cities determines the characteristics of their birds
description: An international team including researchers from the University of Granada (UGR) and the National Museum of Natural Sciences (MNCN-CSIC), has studied the distribution of 115 species of birds in spring and 72 that spend the winter in nine European cities.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Images: Moon, asteroids and new rockets topped the world's space news in 2023
description: The moon, asteroids and brand new rockets topped the world's space news in 2023.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: Finding more sustainable ways to use plastics in agriculture
description: Every year, according to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, some 12.5 million tonnes of plastic are used in agricultural production worldwide. Plastic is a boon to farmers, but leads to large quantities of macro-, micro- and nanoplastics accumulating in soils and other receiving environments. The particles even seep into the food chain.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers review miniaturized electrochemical sensor technologies for rapid heavy metal detection
description: Heavy metals (HMs) are metals with high densities and atomic weights. Originating from geological processes or human activities, including mining, industrial production, and petrochemical plants, they are toxic to humans and animals and considered as common pollutants in the environment.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Long dormant volcanoes can erupt rapidly and explosively, says Ciomadul study
description: Can a volcano erupt after tens of thousands of years of dormancy? If so, how can this be explained and what makes volcanic eruptions more dangerous?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Long-term green manuring strengthens core microbiomes in driving multiple functions across vertical soil profiles: Study
description: A study published in the journal Science China Life Sciences was led by Prof. Weidong Cao (Institute of Agricultural Resources and Regional Planning, Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences) and Prof. Zongxian Che (Institute of Soil and Fertilizer and Water-saving Agriculture, Gansu Academy of Agriculture Sciences).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Encounter with humpback whales reveals potential for nonhuman intelligence communication
description: A team of scientists from the SETI Institute, University of California Davis and the Alaska Whale Foundation, had a close encounter with a non-human (aquatic) intelligence. The Whale-SETI team has been studying humpback whale communication systems in an effort to develop intelligence filters for the search for extraterrestrial intelligence.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Assessing loan applicants' credit risk via smartphone activities helps improve financial inclusion, finds study
description: Financial technology (FinTech)—innovation in the delivery of financial services and products—has grown in popularity, expanding access to finance for millions of people. But while promoting inclusive finance to accelerate economic growth and financial sustainability is considered a good idea, there are challenges to balancing the socioeconomic tradeoffs.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How 'sleeping' microorganisms can determine the fate of a population
description: Microorganisms that temporarily "go to sleep" play an important role in the evolution and survival of a population. Mathematician Shubhamoy Nandan conducted research on the effect of this characteristic called "dormancy" in a novel mathematical model.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study highlights benefits of user-generated content to digital platform
description: Many online platforms (e.g., Huffpost, Wikipedia) host user-generated content (UGC) and content developed by professional reporters.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How a drought led to the rise of skateboarding in 1970s California
description: Why did professional skateboarding arise in southern California in the 1970s? Was it a coincidence, or was it a perfect storm of multiple factors?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: You can always become a better reader, say researchers
description: Our reading skills, and understanding of a text, depend on several factors.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Evidence-based policymaking: New study on international perspectives and best-practice models
description: In order to tackle challenges facing society, such as the energy transition, digitalization, or pandemics, structured, transparent, and fact-based political decision-making processes are needed. Analysis based on science can provide the basis for better-informed decisions.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Viewpoint: The importance of sustainability metrics to sustainability management
description: Every student of management knows that performance measurement is an essential element of effective management. To paraphrase the great management scholar Peter Drucker, you can't manage something if you can't measure it.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Translating humorous children's poetry? Content matters most
description: Translating poetry is notoriously difficult. Translating poetry in such a way that the humorous nature of a poem remains intact is even more difficult, even though it is precisely jokes that can encourage children to read more, notes Ph.D. candidate Alice Morta.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate negotiators eye compromise on fossil fuel exit
description: Negotiators awaited a new draft deal on the fate of fossil fuels as UN climate talks went into overtime in Dubai on Tuesday after nations pushing for a phase-out clashed with Saudi-led oil producers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Blue Origin announces space launch next week, first since 2022 crash
description: Blue Origin said on Tuesday it was aiming to launch its New Shepard suborbital rocket next week, the first mission since an uncrewed crash in September 2022 set back Jeff Bezos' space company.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Warmest Arctic summer caused by accelerating climate change
description: Summer surface air temperatures in 2023 were the warmest ever observed in the Arctic as a result of accelerating human-caused climate change, an official report card published Tuesday said.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: This Japanese 'dragon' terrorized ancient seas
description: Researchers have described a Japanese mosasaur the size of a great white shark that terrorized Pacific seas 72 million years ago.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Waterbird numbers up after La Niña years: Aerial survey
description: Widespread flooding and environmental flows have been a boon for our waterbirds and wetlands—but long-term decline is persisting.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: Polarization in the Netherlands actually is not that bad
description: Discussions about important societal issues, whether they relate to domestic or foreign affairs, on the street and in academia, seem to be intensifying. The heightened tone, personal attacks, and polarization are characteristic of these discussions. Is this a prevailing feature of our time, or is it just our perception? Who should take the lead in countering polarization—the government or citizens?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Supercharged heat waves like Washington's deadliest will strike harder and more often, study says
description: North America's 2021 heat wave was Washington's deadliest weather-related disaster, claiming over 100 lives in the evergreen state and many others in neighboring regions. Scientists not only suggest that such heat waves will grow more intense and strike more often—in new work published in npj Climate and Atmospheric Science, they reveal the underlying mechanism behind these strengthened heat waves.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: California wants farms to capture methane from cow manure. Neighbors say it's killing them
description: At a massive dairy farm in the San Joaquin Valley, nearly 14,000 Holstein cows crane their necks through feeding stalls and gnaw leisurely on alfalfa.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How and when to see the Geminid meteor shower in the UK
description: Stargazers will have a chance to enjoy one of the most spectacular meteor showers of the year later this week, as the Geminids reach their peak.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Livestock associations sue Colorado, U.S. Fish and Wildlife to delay gray wolf reintroduction
description: The Colorado Cattlemen's Association and Gunnison County Stockgrowers' Association sued Colorado Parks and Wildlife and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service this week to delay the reintroduction of gray wolves into Colorado.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: One in three UK men open to having more than one partner, study shows
description: A third of UK men are open to the idea of having more than one wife or long-term girlfriend, according to a new Swansea University study.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Novel early-detection method aims to stem disease spread in animal trade
description: A new article published in the journal Methods in Ecology and Evolution by researchers describes a simplified method to detect a deadly fungus killing European salamanders. The ability to rapidly find the fungus is significant as the disease, although not detected in the U.S., could impact the millions of amphibians and salamanders annually imported.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Video: Permafrost thaw: A silent menace
description: Ice is without doubt one of the first casualties of climate change, but the effects of our warming world are not only limited to ice melting on Earth's surface. Ground that has been frozen for thousands of years, called permafrost, is thawing—adding to the climate crisis and causing serious issues for local communities.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate change causing 60% of plants and insects to fall out of sync
description: Seasonal timings of plants are advancing an average of four times faster than insects, throwing key interactions like pollination out of sync. This is according to new findings from researchers at the University of Oxford and Chinese Academy of Sciences that will be presented at the British Ecological Society Annual Meeting in held Belfast December 12–15.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Finding a better way to use cameras to reduce crime
description: Areas of a middle Georgia city have experienced a 20% reduction in crime after deploying a system of mobile cameras guided by an algorithm developed by Georgia Tech researchers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Replacing 'you' with 'we' can make a message less threatening, and less likely to be censored
description: Ever been in a situation where you just can't get your message across? New research by Zakary Tormala and Mohamed Hussein suggests that you might want to rethink which pronouns you deploy.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Investigating microfiber pollution
description: The fashion industry is facing several growing social and environmental sustainability issues; from clothing textile waste to the prospect of widespread microfiber pollution (MSF). For the latter, we struggle to even define the problem. While we know that huge amounts of microfibers are entering our ecosystems, we don't yet know the impact this is having.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New report outlines opportunities to remove CO2 at the gigaton scale
description: Scientists from more than a dozen institutions have completed a first-of-its-kind high-resolution assessment of carbon dioxide removal potential in the United States, charting a path to achieve a net-zero greenhouse gas economy by 2050.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Zoo-housed carnivores react positively to novel improvements to their enclosures, study suggests
description: Nottingham Trent University research revealed how carnivores became significantly more active and engaged more with their enclosures when given additional enrichment such as different types of feeding, new structures, the introduction of manipulable objects and techniques to trigger their smell senses.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate change imperils Southern California's coastal rail corridor, panelists say
description: Climate change is "wreaking havoc" on the coastal rail corridor from Santa Barbara to San Diego, Sen. Catherine Blakespear said at a Senate Transportation Subcommittee meeting in San Clemente.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers develop chiral boryl radical catalysts in asymmetric catalysis
description: Researchers from the University of Science and Technology of China of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and collaborators, have developed an innovative chiral boryl radical catalysis method, enabling asymmetric catalytic radical cycloisomerization reactions. The study was published in Science.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The hidden impacts of climate change on a freshwater ecosystem
description: From melting glaciers to rising sea levels, from raging wildfires to devastating floods, society has grown increasingly aware of the increasingly frequent climate crises. But what about its subterranean flow? A research group led by Li Dongfeng at the College of Environmental Sciences and Engineering, Peking University (PKU), has published a paper pertaining to this topic in Science Advances.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A new microfabrication strategy for multifunctional 3D artificial sharkskin
description: Sharks in nature swim at high speeds in a deep ocean due to their high drag reduction ability. Water flows around the sharkskin become disrupted by staggered and overlapping microscale structures named denticles. In addition to this surface roughness, water slips at a fluid-solid interface with multiple groove-like microriblets on individual microdenticles.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Environmental stress rather than genetics influenced height differences in early Neolithic people: Study
description: The difference in height between female and male individuals in northern Europe during the Early Neolithic (8,000–6,000 years before present, bp) may have been influenced by cultural factors, a paper published in Nature Human Behaviour suggests. The findings indicate that height differences during this period cannot be explained by genetic and dietary factors alone.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Extremely rare half female, half male bird captured on film
description: A striking and extremely rare half female, half male bird has been spotted by a University of Otago zoologist.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A scheme for realizing nonreciprocal interlayer coupling in bilayer topological systems
description: The exchange of energy and environment is inevitable in any physical system, so non-Hermitian systems that can be described by non-Hermitian Hamiltonians are ubiquitous. There are two kinds of non-Hermitian Hamiltonians, describing nonreciprocal systems with anisotropic coupling, also referred to as nonreciprocal coupling, and gain-loss systems.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists release the recipe for lab-grown coffee to accelerate creation of new coffee ecosystem
description: Two years after the scientists in Finland successfully made coffee in a laboratory, VTT Technical Research Center of Finland Ltd has released detailed information on the process. Published in the Journal of Agriculture and Food Chemistry, the scientific paper describes the exact process the scientists used to produce coffee starting from the original coffee plant itself, and establishing cell cultures to alter its aroma in the roasting process, caffeine content, flavor analysis, and sensory profiling by a panel of tasters.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Fine-tuning gold nanoparticles in tellurite glass for unique photonics
description: Silicate glass is a commonly-used glass found in most households, in drinking glasses or windowpanes for example. The integration of gold nanoparticles (NPs) in silicate glass has been used in art and decoration for centuries. These NPs impact the way the silicate glass interacts with light through the now well-known phenomenon called localized surface plasmon resonance.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Model shows New Zealand should expect 15-meter tsunami every 580 years
description: A team of geographers, Earth scientists and environmental scientists affiliated with several institutions in New Zealand, working with that country's National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research, has found that it is possible to model the number and type of tsunamis that are likely to strike a given area over a given period of time.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New approach overcomes long-standing limitations in optics to enhance the efficiency of Mie scattering
description: When you look up at the sky and see clouds of wondrous shapes, or struggle to peer through dense, hazy fog, you're seeing the results of "Mie scattering," which is what happens with light interacts with particles of a certain size. There is a growing body of research that aims to manipulate this phenomenon and make possible an array of exciting technologies.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The 'one-pot' nanosheet method catalyzing a green energy revolution
description: A research group from the Institute for Future Materials and Systems at Nagoya University in Japan has developed a new 'one-pot' method to make nanosheets using less rare metals. Their discovery should allow for the energy-making process to be more eco-friendly. The journal ACS Nano published the study.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Research progress in pump-probe experiments at high-intensity laser facilities
description: The reaction kinetics of energetic materials is a key factor in determining the detonation characteristics and safety. The complexity of the reaction process and the lack of experimental means remain a notable challenge in experimental research and fine modeling. To accurately predict the detonation and safety properties of energetic materials, it is necessary to clarify the reaction mechanism and dynamic process.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New study sheds light on how much methane is produced from Arctic lakes and wetlands
description: When it comes to greenhouse gases, methane is one the biggest contributors. Not only is it massively abundant—it's about 25 times more potent than carbon dioxide at trapping heat in the atmosphere.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Field-induced superconductivity in quantum materials
description: Field-induced superconductivity occurs when an applied magnetic field increases or induces superconductivity. In a new report published in Science Advances, Joshua J. Sanchez and a team of scientists applied stress as a switch between a field tunable superconducting state and a robust non-field tunable state, to mark the first demonstration of a strain-tunable, superconducting spin valve with infinite magnetoresistance.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New plasma instability sheds light on the nature of cosmic rays
description: Scientists from the Leibniz Institute for Astrophysics Potsdam (AIP) have discovered a new plasma instability that promises to revolutionize our understanding of the origin of cosmic rays and their dynamic impact on galaxies.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Daily singing workout keeps songbird males attractive, study shows
description: Every year in the Christmas season it becomes clear again that some people are amazingly skilled singers, like Mariah Carey and George Michael. Their singing can stir strong emotions.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Jordan's mission to save its ancient olive trees
description: Every morning, Jordanian farmer Ali Saleh Atta swallows two cloves of garlic with a cup of olive oil before heading out to check on his ancient olive trees.

album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Japan zoo probes possible mass squirrel poisoning
description: A Japanese zoo has launched a probe after apparently massacring 31 of its 40 squirrels by mistake with treatments meant to kill parasites, officials said.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: UN climate summit runs overtime as fury mounts on fossil fuels
description: The world's climate negotiators on Tuesday haggled beyond a host-imposed deadline for a deal as at-risk nations voiced fury over a proposed compromise that stops short of phasing out fossil fuels.
